Federated Learning in the Presence of Adversarial Client Unavailabilityâ€ â€ thanks: L.Â Su is supported by the ARO Grant W911NF-23-2-0014. J.Â Xu is supported by the NSF Grants CCF-1856424 and CCF-2144593. P.Â Yang is supported by the NSFC Grant 12101353 and Tsinghua University Initiative Scientific Research Program.

Lili Su
Electrical and Computer Engineering
Northeastern University â€ƒâ€ƒ Jiaming Xu
The Fuqua School of Business
Duke University â€ƒâ€ƒ Pengkun Yang
Center for Statistical Science
Tsinghua University
Abstract

Federated learning is a decentralized machine learning framework wherein not all clients are able to participate in each round. An emerging line of research is devoted to tackling arbitrary client unavailability. Existing theoretical analysis imposes restrictive structural assumptions on the unavailability patterns, and their proposed algorithms were tailored to those assumptions.

In this paper, we relax those assumptions and consider adversarial client unavailability. To quantify the degrees of client unavailability, we use the notion of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction. For both non-convex and strongly-convex global objectives, we show that simple variants of FedAvg or FedProx, albeit completely agnostic to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, converge to an estimation error on the order of Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2\epsilon(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}), where GğºG is a heterogeneity parameter and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the noise level. We prove that this estimation error is minimax-optimal. We also show that the variants of FedAvg or FedProx have convergence speeds Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex objectives and Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/T) for strongly-convex objectives, both of which are the best possible for any first-order method that only has access to noisy gradients. Our proofs build upon a tight analysis of the selection bias that persists in the entire learning process. We validate our theoretical prediction through numerical experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

1 Introduction

Federated learning is a decentralized machine learning framework, wherein the clients coordinate with a parameter server without disclosing local data [MMR+17, KMA+21]. Cross-device federated learning is often massive in scale, making full client participation impractical [MMR+17]. Most existing work either assumes that client unavailability follows benign distributions [MMR+17, LHY+20, RZLJW21, PD20] or that the parameter server can arbitrarily recruit participants [CWJ22], i.e., a client reached out by the parameter server must follow its computation requests. However, these assumptions rarely hold in practice unless the training environments are under good control.

As pointed out in the seminal work [MMR+17], real-world federated learning is often deployed in non-controllable environments, and the availability of a client depends (in a complicated way) on multiple time-varying factors such as external interruptions and hardware/software status. For instance, when the clients are mobile devices, a client may not respond to a computation request if disconnected from WiFi. As another example, a client may suddenly abort the training process due to interruptions caused by low battery and other prioritized tasks.

As such, there is a recent surge of interest in studying arbitrary client unavailabilityÂ [GHZH21, WJ22, YND+20, YZKL22]. Despite that they collectively laid a solid foundation in this direction, this line of work still imposes stringent structural assumptions on unavailability patterns such as regularized participation [WJ22], bounded inactive periods [YND+20, YZKL22, GHZH21], and asymptotic unbounded inactive periods [GHZH21]. Existing algorithm designs and analysis are tailored to those specific assumptions; see Section 2 for details. It is easy to find patterns that violate the aforementioned assumptions. For example, a client may be inactive for a while and become active at some carefully chosen time in order to disturb the learning process. Overall, there is a wide spectrum of client unavailability modes that are not well covered by existing works.

In this paper, we relax those structural assumptions and consider adversarial client unavailability. Specifically, in each round first the parameter server randomly samples Kğ¾K clients, and then a system adversary can â€“ based on all the information up to now â€“ adaptively select a subset of sampled clients to be non-responsive. To quantify the degrees of client unavailability, we use the notion of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction. We show that simple variants of the standard FedAvg or FedProx algorithms, albeit agnostic to the degree of client unavailability Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, turn out to be optimal. We further validate our theoretical prediction through numerical experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

Concretely, we study a canonical setup in which the goal is to minimize Fâ€‹(Î¸)â‰œâˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹Fiâ€‹(Î¸)â‰œğ¹ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒF(\theta)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}F_{i}(\theta) when only noisy stochastic gradients are available, where wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} is the weight and Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} is the local objective of client iâˆˆ[M]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€i\in[M]. The local data is non-IID yet satisfies the standard (B,G)ğµğº(B,G)-heterogeneity condition [KMA+21] (formally described inÂ AssumptionÂ 1). Our main theoretical results can be summarized succinctly in the following informal theorem.

Theorem 1 (Informal).

When Fğ¹F is non-convex, let â„›â€‹(Î¸^):=â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸^)â€–2assignâ„›^ğœƒsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹^ğœƒ2{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}):=\|\nabla F(\widehat{\theta})\|^{2}; when Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex, let â„›â€‹(Î¸^):=Î¼2â€‹â€–Î¸^âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–22assignâ„›^ğœƒsuperscriptğœ‡2superscriptsubscriptnorm^ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒ22{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}):=\mu^{2}\|\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\|_{2}^{2}, where Î¸âˆ—=argâ¡minâ¡Fâ€‹(Î¸)superscriptğœƒğ¹ğœƒ\theta^{*}=\arg\min F(\theta). Let Ïƒğœ\sigma be the average noise level of the stochastic gradients. Then

infÎ¸^supğ’œsupF1,â‹¯,FMğ”¼â€‹[â„›â€‹(Î¸^)]â‰Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2),asymptotically-equalssubscriptinfimum^ğœƒsubscriptsupremumğ’œsubscriptsupremumsubscriptğ¹1â‹¯subscriptğ¹ğ‘€ğ”¼delimited-[]â„›^ğœƒitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2\inf_{\widehat{\theta}}\sup_{{\mathcal{A}}}\sup_{F_{1},\cdots,F_{M}}\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta})\right]~{}\asymp~{}{\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)},

where supF1,â‹¯,FMsubscriptsupremumsubscriptğ¹1â‹¯subscriptğ¹ğ‘€\sup_{F_{1},\cdots,F_{M}} is taken over all local objectives that collectively satisfy the (B,G)ğµğº(B,G)-heterogeneity condition, ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} is all adversarial client unavailability subject to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction, and infÎ¸^subscriptinfimum^ğœƒ\inf_{\widehat{\theta}} is taken over all algorithms Î¸^^ğœƒ\widehat{\theta} that have only access to noisy local gradients.

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    The achievability of Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2))ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) is proved in SectionÂ 4.1 by analyzing variants of FedAvg or FedProx. We also characterize their convergence speeds and show that â„›â€‹(Î¸^t)â„›subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta}_{t}) approaches Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2))ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) at a speed of Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex functions (with general form in Theorem 2 and explicit speeds in Corollary 1) and Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/T) for strongly-convex functions (Theorem 3). These convergence speeds are on par with the centralized settingsÂ [GL13, NJLS09], and are the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradientsÂ [ACD+22, GHZH21].

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    The impossibility of oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2))ğ‘œitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2o(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)) is shown in Section 5 (Theorem 4).

Interestingly, among the two heterogeneity parameters BğµB and GğºG, only GğºG appears in the estimation error Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2))ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2O(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)). Our analysis reveals that BğµB instead influences the convergence speed.

It is worth noting that our adversarial client unavailability model can be viewed as a special case of Byzantine attacks [Lyn96, BDPPBT19]. Nevertheless, existing Byzantine-resilient results are not applicable to our problem. A distinctive feature of our problem is that the set of faulty clients is changing over time, which results in selection bias that may accumulate throughout the entire process. Specifically, at every round the adversary can inspect all the local gradients and all the past information to adaptively select a subset of clients to be non-responsive. This selection bias is largely overlooked in existing Byzantine-resilient FL literature. We defer detailed discussions toÂ AppendixÂ A.

2 Related work

Random client unavailability. Random client unavailability has received intensive attention in recent yearsÂ [KMA+21]. Previous studies [MMR+17, LHY+20, YL22] assumed that the parameter server can successfully recruit Kğ¾K clients uniformly at random or proportionally to clientsâ€™ local data volume in each round. Such client sampling methods are not applicable when some clients are not responsive. Additionally, the analysis on the fast responses [LHY+20, PD20, KMA+21, WJ22] assumed that each client responds with a known probability. A generalized version of random client unavailability patterns is proposed inÂ [RZLJW21], where during each round the number of local updates at a client follows a distribution with support on {0,1,â‹¯,s}01â‹¯ğ‘ \{0,1,\cdots,s\}, where sğ‘ s is the number of local updates.

Arbitrary client unavailability. Only a handful of work exists on arbitrary client unavailability [YND+20, GHZH21, WJ22, YZKL22, CWJ22]. BothÂ [YND+20] andÂ [CWJ22] focus on controllable environments, where every client sampled by the parameter server must respond accordingly. [YND+20] considered non-convex optimization with one-step local updates, and proposed FedLaAvg which was shown to be resilient to bounded inactive periods. When the local objectives are strongly-convex, [CWJ22] showed that convergence can be expedited if the parameter server strategically recruits clients based on the current global model. In comparison, we consider the practical scenario where some sampled clients fail to respond to the computation requests. Non-controllable environments were investigated more recently [GHZH21, WJ22, YZKL22]. [GHZH21] considered both strongly-convex and non-convex objectives, and proposed MIFA which shares similar ideas as FedLaAvg yet requires full client participation in the first round. For strongly-convex objectives, [GHZH21] characterized the unavailability patterns that each client needs to obey, which require clients to be frequently available during the early training stage (i.e., when tğ‘¡t is small). For non-convex objectives, MIFA was shown to tolerate bounded inactive periods [GHZH21]. Assuming that the client unavailability pattern is known and the local objectives F1,â‹¯,FMsubscriptğ¹1â‹¯subscriptğ¹ğ‘€F_{1},\cdots,F_{M} satisfy the (B,G)ğµğº(B,G)-heterogeneity condition with B=0ğµ0B=0. [WJ22] came up with a unified analysis for a generalized version of FedAvg wherein the global model updates are amplified periodically. Unfortunately, their analysis does not go through for adversarial client unavailability because of the bias introduced by the adversarial selection of the non-responsive clients. [YZKL22] considered an interesting setup wherein, instead of passively waiting to be recruited, the clients decide on when and how to participate in federated learning. However, clients in [YZKL22] are restricted to make decisions without using any historical information in order to ensure some independence property. Without such independence, the conditional expectation involved in the proof of [YZKL22, Lemma 2] is biased; hence Lemma 2 no longer holds. Similarly, the derivation of the term A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} in their proof of Theorem 4 breaks down.

3 Problem setup

Learning objective. A parameter server and Mğ‘€M clients collaboratively minimize

minÎ¸âˆˆâ„dâ¡Fâ€‹(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹Fiâ€‹(Î¸),subscriptğœƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¹ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒ\displaystyle\min_{\theta\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}}F(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}F_{i}(\theta), (1)

where Fiâ€‹(Î¸)=ğ”¼zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹[â„“iâ€‹(Î¸;z)]subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘§subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğœƒğ‘§F_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim{\mathcal{D}}_{i}}[\ell_{i}(\theta;z)] is the local objective, wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} is the weight, ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i} is the local data distribution, and â„“iâ€‹(Î¸;z)subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğœƒğ‘§\ell_{i}(\theta;z) is a loss function. The local datasets can be unbalanced across clients. Let nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} denote the number of data points generated from the unknown ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i} at every round by client iğ‘–i, and N=âˆ‘i=1Mniğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–N=\sum_{i=1}^{M}n_{i} be the total number of data points drawn at every round. Following the literature [LSZ+20, LHY+20, YL22, KKM+20] we adopt the following bounded dissimilarity assumption.

Assumption 1 (Bounded dissimilarity).

We say that (wi,Fi)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–(w_{i},F_{i}) satisfies the (B,G)ğµğº(B,G)-bounded dissimilarity condition for Bâ‰¥1ğµ1B\geq 1 and Gâ‰¥0ğº0G\geq 0 if âˆ‘iâˆˆ[M]wiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸)â€–22â‰¤B2â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸)â€–22+G2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒ22superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹ğœƒ22superscriptğº2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}+G^{2}.

When the local datasets are IID (i.e., ğ’Ÿi=ğ’Ÿjsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—{\mathcal{D}}_{i}={\mathcal{D}}_{j} for any i,jâˆˆ[M]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘€i,j\in[M]), it holds that B=1ğµ1B=1 and G=0ğº0G=0 as Fi=Fsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ¹F_{i}=F for all clients. When data is non-IID, more stringent forms of bounded dissimilarity assumptions are popular in the existing literature on arbitrary client unavailability and Byzantine resilience. For example, [YND+20] and [CWJ22] assumed bounded gradients, i.e., âˆ‘iâˆˆ[M]wiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸)â€–22â‰¤G2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒ22superscriptğº2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}. Both [WJ22] and [YZKL22] assumed âˆ‘iâˆˆ[M]wiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸)â€–22â‰¤G2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒâˆ‡ğ¹ğœƒ22superscriptğº2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}. Byzantine resilience was shown in [KHJ22, AFG+23] assuming either G=0ğº0G=0 or âˆ‘iâˆˆ[M]wiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸)â€–22â‰¤G2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒâˆ‡ğ¹ğœƒ22superscriptğº2\sum_{i\in[M]}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla F_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F(\theta)}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}.

Adversarial Client Unavailability. In each round tğ‘¡t, first the parameter server uniformly at random selects a set ğ’®~tâŠ‚[M]subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘€\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\subset[M] of Kğ¾K clients without replacement. Each client iâˆˆğ’®~tğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} draws a fresh sample zi,tsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡z_{i,t} of size nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} from the local dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. Let p=K/Mğ‘ğ¾ğ‘€p=K/M. Similar client selection was considered in [MMR+17, KMA+21, JSNJ22]. Then the adversary adaptively chooses the set ğ’®tâŠ‚ğ’®~tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\subset\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} of participating clients. The adversaryâ€™s choice of ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} may depend on the sets of local data points {zi,Ï„:Ï„â‰¤t,iâˆˆ[M]}conditional-setsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœformulae-sequenceğœğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€\{z_{i,\tau}:\tau\leq t,i\in[M]\} drawn by all clients up to time tğ‘¡t and the sets of participating clients {ğ’®Ï„,Ï„â‰¤tâˆ’1}subscriptğ’®ğœğœğ‘¡1\{{\mathcal{S}}_{\tau},\tau\leq t-1\} chosen previously. We also allow the adversary to have total access to all system parameters including nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} and local objective functions Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i}. In other words, the adversary is fully aware of everything that happened up to time tğ‘¡t. Such adaptive choice of â€œfaultyâ€ clients is standard in distributed computing literature [Lyn96, BDPPBT19, CM16].

To further quantify the degrees of client unavailability, below we impose an upper bound on the total number of data points that are dropped by the adversary at every round t.ğ‘¡t.

Assumption 2 (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-adversary dropout fraction).

âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~tâˆ–ğ’®tniâ‰¤Ïµâ€‹Kâ€‹NM,âˆ€t.subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘ğ‘€for-allğ‘¡\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}n_{i}\leq\epsilon\frac{KN}{M},\quad\forall t.

Roughly speaking, since ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~tni]=Kâ€‹N/Mğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘€\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}}n_{i}\right]=KN/M, Â AssumptionÂ 2 says that on average at most Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon fraction of the sampled data points can be further dropped out by the adversary. In the data balanced setting where ni=N/Msubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘€n_{i}=N/M for all iğ‘–i, AssumptionÂ 2 simplifies to |ğ’®~tâˆ–ğ’®t|â‰¤Ïµâ€‹Ksubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡italic-Ïµğ¾|\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}|\leq\epsilon K, that is, at most Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-fraction of clients in ğ’®~tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} are non-responsive.

4 Algorithms and convergence guarantees

Algorithms. We analyze variants of FedAvg and FedProx in this section. Formally, in each communication round tğ‘¡t, each client iâˆˆğ’®tğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t} updates the model based on the local function â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â‰œ1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1niâ„“iâ€‹(Î¸;zi,t(j))â‰œsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘—\ell_{i,t}(\theta)\triangleq\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\ell_{i}(\theta;z_{i,t}^{(j)}), where zi,t=(zi,t(1),â€¦,zi,t(ni))subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–z_{i,t}=(z_{i,t}^{(1)},\dots,z_{i,t}^{(n_{i})}) is a fresh sample batch of size nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    FedAvg: First, set Î¸i,t0=Î¸tsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒ0ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\,\theta^{0}_{i,t}=\theta_{t}; then perform sğ‘ s local updates as Î¸i,tÏ„+1=Î¸i,tÏ„âˆ’Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸i,tÏ„)subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğœ1ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğœğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğœğ‘–ğ‘¡\theta^{\tau+1}_{i,t}=\theta^{\tau}_{i,t}-\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta^{\tau}_{i,t})â€‰ for Ï„=0,â‹¯,sâˆ’1ğœ0â‹¯ğ‘ 1\tau=0,\cdots,s-1; finally, set Î¸i,t+1=Î¸i,tssubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘¡\theta_{i,t+1}=\theta^{s}_{i,t}.

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    FedProx111We assume the exact minimizer for ease of presentation. Our results can be readily extended when Î¸i,t+1subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1\theta_{i,t+1} is an approximate solution, see e.g., [LSZ+20, Definition 2] and [YL22, Definition 3].: Î¸i,t+1âˆˆargâ¡minzâ¡â„“i,tâ€‹(z)+12â€‹Î·tâ€‹â€–zâˆ’Î¸tâ€–22.subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘§subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘§12subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘§subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22\theta_{i,t+1}\in\arg\min_{z}\ell_{i,t}(z)+\frac{1}{2\eta_{t}}\left\|{z-\theta_{t}}\right\|_{2}^{2}.

Upon receiving the local model update Î¸i,t+1subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1\theta_{i,t+1} from active clients in ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} the parameter server computes

Î¸t+1=Î¸t+Î²â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸t),subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}=\theta_{t}+\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\left(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}\right), (2)

where Î²>0ğ›½0\beta>0 is a parameter introduced to compensate for the lack of participation of the unavailable and non-sampled clients.

Assumptions. In the sequel, we analyze the convergence property of the algorithms. We assume throughout this section that each local gradient function âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta) is Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}-Lipschitz for all tğ‘¡t, that is,

â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(u)âˆ’âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(v)â€–2â‰¤Liâ€‹â€–uâˆ’vâ€–2.subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¢âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘£2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘£2\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(u)-\nabla\ell_{i,t}(v)}\right\|_{2}\leq L_{i}\left\|{u-v}\right\|_{2}. (3)

Such smoothness condition is commonly used in the convergence analysis of federated learning algorithms (see e.g.Â [LSZ+20, YL22]). Define Lâ‰œmaxiâˆˆ[M]â¡Liâ‰œğ¿subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€subscriptğ¿ğ‘–L\triangleq\max_{i\in[M]}L_{i}. For FedProx, we additionally assume that

Î»minâ€‹(âˆ‡2â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸))â‰¥âˆ’Lâˆ’,âˆ€i,andâ€‹âˆ€t.subscriptğœ†superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒsubscriptğ¿for-allğ‘–andfor-allğ‘¡\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\geq-L_{-},\quad\forall i,~{}\text{and}~{}\forall t. (4)

The condition is commonly adopted in the analysis of proximal gradient descent [LSZ+20]. It ensures that, using a sufficiently small Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t}, the objective function in FedProx is strongly convex, and hence the solution is unique and can be efficiently found.

Let â„±tsubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡{\mathcal{F}}_{t} denote the filtration generated by the sequence {zi,Ï„,ğ’®Ï„:Ï„â‰¤tâˆ’1,iâˆˆ[M]}.conditional-setsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœsubscriptğ’®ğœformulae-sequenceğœğ‘¡1ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€\{z_{i,\tau},{\mathcal{S}}_{\tau}:\tau\leq t-1,i\in[M]\}. Then Î¸tâˆˆâ„±tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\theta_{t}\in{\mathcal{F}}_{t}. It follows from our problem setup that ğ’®~tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t} and zi,tsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡z_{i,t} for iâˆˆ[M]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€i\in[M] are independent of â„±tsubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡{\mathcal{F}}_{t}. We assume the regularity condition that âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}) is an unbiased estimate of âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\nabla F_{i}(\theta_{t}) conditioned on â„±tsubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡{\mathcal{F}}_{t}:

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ£â„±t]=Fiâ€‹(Î¸t),ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]=F_{i}(\theta_{t}), (5)
ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ’Fiâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–22âˆ£â„±t]â‰¤Ïƒi2.ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})-F_{i}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\leq\sigma_{i}^{2}. (6)

Let Ïƒ2=âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹Ïƒi2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2\sigma^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2} denote the average noise level.

4.1 Non-convex functions

Theorem 2.

Let Fminâ‰œinfÎ¸Fâ€‹(Î¸)â‰œsubscriptğ¹subscriptinfimumğœƒğ¹ğœƒF_{\min}\triangleq\inf_{\theta}F(\theta). Suppose that Ïµâ€‹B<0.8italic-Ïµğµ0.8\sqrt{\epsilon}B<0.8. Let Rğ‘…R be the random time with â„™â€‹[R=k]=Î·k/âˆ‘t=0TÎ·tâ„™delimited-[]ğ‘…ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\mathbb{P}[R=k]=\eta_{k}/\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t} for k=0,â€¦,T.ğ‘˜0â€¦ğ‘‡k=0,\dots,T. For FedAvg, suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, and choose Î·tâ‰¤110â€‹Î²â€‹sâ€‹Lâ€‹B2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡110ğ›½ğ‘ ğ¿superscriptğµ2\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{10\beta sLB^{2}} for all tğ‘¡t. For FedProx, suppose that Assumptions 1, 2 and the condition in Eq.(4) hold, and choose Î·tâ‰¤110â€‹Î²â€‹Lâ€‹B2âˆ§110â€‹Lâˆ’subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡110ğ›½ğ¿superscriptğµ2110subscriptğ¿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{10\beta LB^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{10L_{-}} for all tğ‘¡t. Then, for both FedAvg and FedProx, there exists a universal constant cğ‘c such that

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸R)â€–22â‰¤3â€‹(Fâ€‹(Î¸0)âˆ’Fmin)Î²â€‹pâ€‹sâ€‹âˆ‘t=0TÎ·t+câ€‹(Ïµ+Î²â€‹sâ€‹Lâ€‹âˆ‘t=0TÎ·t2âˆ‘t=0TÎ·t)â€‹(G+Ïƒ)2,ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘…223ğ¹subscriptğœƒ0subscriptğ¹ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘italic-Ïµğ›½ğ‘ ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptğºğœ2\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{3\left(F(\theta_{0})-F_{\min}\right)}{\beta ps\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}}+c\left(\epsilon+\frac{\beta sL\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}^{2}}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}}\right)\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}, (7)

where s=1ğ‘ 1s=1 for FedProx. Consequently, let Î¸^=Î¸R^ğœƒsubscriptğœƒğ‘…\widehat{\theta}=\theta_{R} with âˆ‘t=0TÎ·tâ†’âˆâ†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}\to\infty and âˆ‘t=0TÎ·t2âˆ‘t=0TÎ·tâ†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\frac{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}^{2}}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}}\to 0. Then,

limTâ†’âˆğ”¼â€‹â€–Fâ€‹(Î¸^)â€–2â‰¤Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)).subscriptâ†’ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormğ¹^ğœƒ2ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\lim_{T\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\|F(\widehat{\theta})\|^{2}\leq O\left(\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)\right). (8)

We remark that the assumption Ïµâ€‹B<0.8italic-Ïµğµ0.8\sqrt{\epsilon}B<0.8 is to some extent necessary. Intuitively, if BğµB gets larger, Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i}â€™s become more dissimilar and hence fewer adversarial dropouts can be tolerated. SeeÂ RemarkÂ 4 in AppendixÂ D for more detailed discussion.

Below we show the convergence rates under some concrete schemes of the learning rate based onÂ TheoremÂ 2. In the first case, Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} depends on the eventual termination time Tğ‘‡T, which may be chosen based on a prescribed level of optimality; in the second case, Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} is independent of Tğ‘‡T, so the program can be executed indefinitely. We only present the results for the FedAvg, and the results for the FedProx are entirely analogous yet with s=1ğ‘ 1s=1. Let Î”=Fâ€‹(Î¸0)âˆ’FminÎ”ğ¹subscriptğœƒ0subscriptğ¹\Delta=F(\theta_{0})-F_{\min}. Recall that p=K/Mğ‘ğ¾ğ‘€p=K/M.

Corollary 1.

For FedAvg: Choose Î·t=110â€‹Î²â€‹Lâ€‹B2âˆ§1Î²â€‹pâ€‹Tâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡110ğ›½ğ¿superscriptğµ21ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ¿ğºğœ\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{10\beta LB^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma)}. Then

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸R)â€–22â‰¤Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)2)+Oâ€‹(Î”â€‹Lâ€‹B2/(pâ€‹sâ€‹T)+(Î”+1)â€‹(G+Ïƒ)â€‹sâ€‹L/pâ€‹T).ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘…22ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğºğœ2ğ‘‚Î”ğ¿superscriptğµ2ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‡Î”1ğºğœğ‘ ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq O\left(\epsilon\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}\right)+O\left(\Delta LB^{2}/(psT)+(\Delta+1)\left(G+\sigma\right)s\sqrt{L/pT}\right).

Choose Î·t=Î·0t+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘¡1\eta_{t}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{\sqrt{t+1}} for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0, where Î·0=110â€‹Î²â€‹Lâ€‹B2âˆ§1Î²â€‹pâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)subscriptğœ‚0110ğ›½ğ¿superscriptğµ21ğ›½ğ‘ğ¿ğºğœ\eta_{0}=\frac{1}{10\beta LB^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)}. Then

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸R)â€–22â‰¤Oâ€‹(Ïµâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)2)+Oâ€‹(Î”â€‹Lâ€‹B2/(pâ€‹sâ€‹T)+(Î”+1)â€‹(G+Ïƒ)â€‹sâ€‹Lâ€‹log2â¡T/pâ€‹T).ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘…22ğ‘‚italic-Ïµsuperscriptğºğœ2ğ‘‚Î”ğ¿superscriptğµ2ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‡Î”1ğºğœğ‘ ğ¿superscript2ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq O\left(\epsilon\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}\right)+O\left(\Delta LB^{2}/(ps\sqrt{T})+(\Delta+1)\left(G+\sigma\right)s\sqrt{L\log^{2}T/pT}\right).

The rate Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) matches that of the standard stochastic gradient descent for optimizing non-convex functions [GL13]. In fact, the rate Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients (see e.g.Â [ACD+22, Theorem 3]). SeeÂ AppendixÂ B for details.

Remark 1.

The random termination time Rğ‘…R in TheoremÂ 2 is not revealed to the adversary. Alternatively, the parameter server can choose a random point Î¸Rsubscriptğœƒğ‘…\theta_{R} after running the program for Tğ‘‡T global rounds. The statement is equivalent to the upper bound of some properly weighted average of gradient norms during the Tğ‘‡T rounds. Furthermore, it implies the same upper bound for the minimum gradient norm over those rounds;

4.2 Convex functions

The global objective function Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex for some Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0 if

âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(y),xâˆ’yâŸ©â‰¥Î¼â€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–22,âˆ€x,y.âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦22for-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦\displaystyle\left\langle\nabla F(x)-\nabla F(y),x-y\right\rangle\geq\mu\left\|{x-y}\right\|_{2}^{2},\quad\forall x,y. (9)

It is worth noting that the convergence results here only require the global objective Fğ¹F to be strongly convex; each local objective Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} can still be non-convex. This is slightly more relaxed compared with what is typically imposed in the federated learning literature. For instance, the local population functions Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} at every client are assumed to be Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex inÂ [LHY+20, KKM+20, GHZH21].

Theorem 3.

Suppose that Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and Bâ€‹Ïµ<0.8â€‹Î¼Lğµitalic-Ïµ0.8ğœ‡ğ¿B\sqrt{\epsilon}<0.8\frac{\mu}{L}. For FedAvg, suppose that AssumptionsÂ 1 and 2 hold, and choose Î·t=Î¸/(t+Î³)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœƒğ‘¡ğ›¾\eta_{t}=\theta/(t+\gamma) for constants Î¸,Î³ğœƒğ›¾\theta,\gamma such that Ï=câ€‹Î²â€‹pâ€‹sâ€‹Î¸â€‹Î¼>1ğœŒğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘ ğœƒğœ‡1\rho=c\beta ps\theta\mu>1 and Î·tâ‰¤Î¼10â€‹Î²â€‹sâ€‹L2â€‹B2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‡10ğ›½ğ‘ superscriptğ¿2superscriptğµ2\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\mu}{10\beta sL^{2}B^{2}} for all tğ‘¡t. For FedProx, suppose that AssumptionsÂ 1, 2 and the condition in Eq.(4) hold, and choose Î·t=Î¸/(t+Î³)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœƒğ‘¡ğ›¾\eta_{t}=\theta/(t+\gamma) for constants Î¸,Î³ğœƒğ›¾\theta,\gamma such that Ï=câ€‹Î²â€‹pâ€‹Î¸â€‹Î¼>1ğœŒğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ğœƒğœ‡1\rho=c\beta p\theta\mu>1 and Î·tâ‰¤Î¼10â€‹Î²â€‹L2â€‹B2âˆ§110â€‹Lâˆ’subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‡10ğ›½superscriptğ¿2superscriptğµ2110subscriptğ¿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\mu}{10\beta L^{2}B^{2}}\wedge\frac{1}{10L_{-}} for all tğ‘¡t. Then, for both FedAvg and FedProx, there exists some universal constants c,câ€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²c,c^{\prime},

ğ”¼â€‹â€–Î¸tâˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–22â‰¤(1+tÎ³)âˆ’Ïâ€‹â€–Î¸0âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–22+câ€²â€‹ÏµÎ¼2â€‹(G+Ïƒ)2+câ€²â€‹Ï2(Ïâˆ’1)â€‹pâ€‹Î¼2â€‹(G+Ïƒ)2â€‹1t+Î³.ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡superscriptğœƒ22superscript1ğ‘¡ğ›¾ğœŒsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒ0superscriptğœƒ22superscriptğ‘â€²italic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ‡2superscriptğºğœ2superscriptğ‘â€²superscriptğœŒ2ğœŒ1ğ‘superscriptğœ‡2superscriptğºğœ21ğ‘¡ğ›¾\mathbb{E}\left\|{\theta_{t}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\left(1+\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{-\rho}\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{c^{\prime}\epsilon}{\mu^{2}}\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}+c^{\prime}\frac{\rho^{2}}{(\rho-1)p\mu^{2}}\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}\frac{1}{t+\gamma}.

Note that Î¼/Lğœ‡ğ¿\mu/L is an upper bound to the condition number of Hessian matrix âˆ‡2F.superscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹\nabla^{2}F. Thus, our standing condition Bâ€‹Ïµ<0.8â€‹Î¼Lğµitalic-Ïµ0.8ğœ‡ğ¿B\sqrt{\epsilon}<0.8\frac{\mu}{L} indicates that a larger fraction of adversarial dropouts can be tolerated when the population function Fğ¹F is better conditioned.

TheoremÂ 3 shows that Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} converges to Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*} at a rate of Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(1/t). The Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(1/t) convergence rate is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients [NJLS09], [GHZH21, Theorem E.1]. When there is no adversarial dropout, our results reduce to the state-of-art convergence results for FedAvg or FedProx. For instance, an exponential decay term similar to (1+t/Î³)âˆ’Ïâ€‹â€–Î¸0âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–2superscript1ğ‘¡ğ›¾ğœŒsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒ0superscriptğœƒ2(1+t/\gamma)^{-\rho}\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2} and a linear decay term similar to (Ïƒ2+G2)/tsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğº2ğ‘¡(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})/t also appear inÂ [KKM+20, Theorem V]. The convergence results in [LHY+20] are similar but a bit weaker: there is a linear decay term similar to (Ïƒ2+G2)/tsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğº2ğ‘¡(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})/t, but the error bound decays only linearly rather than exponentially in the initial error as â€–Î¸0âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–2/tsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒ0superscriptğœƒ2ğ‘¡\left\|{\theta_{0}-\theta^{*}}\right\|_{2}/t.

4.3 Proof sketch of the main theorems

We provide a general proof roadmap of our main theorems and discuss the connections and differences from existing SGD analysis. The sketch focuses on the FedAvg in the general non-convex functions setting. The cases for FedProx or strongly convex functions can be shown via similar arguments.

Following the standard analysis of smooth objective functions,

Fâ€‹(Î¸t+1)â‰¤Fâ€‹(Î¸t)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t),Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tâŸ©+L2â€‹â€–Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tâ€–22.ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ¿2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22F(\theta_{t+1})\leq F(\theta_{t})+\left\langle\nabla F(\theta_{t}),\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. (10)

The progress over one communication round Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} per aggregation ruleÂ (2) is given by Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸t=Î²â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸t).subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}). The classical SGD iteration relies on the unbiasedness of Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t} for the direction of âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡-\nabla F(\theta_{t}). The unbiasedness fails to hold due to the following two reasons:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Objective inconsistency. Under FedAvg or FedProx, the clients either run multiple-step of local SGD or solve a subroutine with proximity regularization. The bias of local updates arises from objective inconsistency or client-drift as analyzed by [WLL+20, KKM+20] for FedAvg. For FedAvg, define

    Btğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒâ‰œâˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸tâˆ’(âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t))).â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡B_{t}^{\sf obj}\triangleq\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}-(-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))).
  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Selection bias. Given the sampled clients S~tsubscript~ğ‘†ğ‘¡\widetilde{S}_{t}, the non-responsive clients ğ’®~t/ğ’®tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t} are selected by by the system adversary; consequently, the resulting participating clients ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} no longer form a representative subset of all clients. Whatâ€™s more, the adversarial selection is time-varying and may even be correlated with the data used to evaluate the local gradients. Define

    Btğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…â‰œâˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t).â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡B_{t}^{\sf sel}\triangleq\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}).

Therefore, the major challenge is to quantify the biases from the above two sources carefully.

Objective inconsistency.

We first upper-bound the deviation from the desired direction as

â€–Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸tâˆ’(âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t))â€–2â‰²s2â€‹Î·t2â€‹Lâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2,less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2ğ¿subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2\|{\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}-(-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))}\|_{2}\lesssim s^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2},

uniformly for all possible Î¸t,subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t}, provided that the local learning rate Î·tâ‰²1sâ€‹Lless-than-or-similar-tosubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1ğ‘ ğ¿\eta_{t}\lesssim\frac{1}{sL}. The precise result is stated in LemmaÂ 1 in Appendix C.1.1. For each client, the stochastic variation of â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})-\nabla F_{i}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2} follows from (6). Then, byÂ AssumptionÂ 1, the collective deviation is upper bounded by

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~twiâ€‹s2â€‹Î·t2â€‹Lâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2âˆ£â„±t]â‰¤pâ€‹s2â€‹Î·t2â€‹Lâ€‹(Bâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2+G+Ïƒ).ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2ğ¿subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2ğ¿ğµsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2ğºğœ\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}s^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\leq ps^{2}\eta_{t}^{2}L\left(B\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\|_{2}+G+\sigma\right). (11)
Selection bias.

Since ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} is time-varying and is correlated with âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}), we upper-bound the bias uniformly via the analysis of extreme values. Two main ingredients in our analysis are: 1) the power of the adversary is limited as specified by AssumptionÂ 2; 2) the dissimilarity among the clients is bounded given by AssumptionÂ 1. Combining those two ingredients, we prove that

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Btğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…â€–2âˆ£â„±t]â‰²pâ€‹Ïµâ€‹(Bâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2+G+Ïƒ)less-than-or-similar-toğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…2subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡ğ‘italic-Ïµğµsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2ğºğœ\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{B_{t}^{\sf sel}}\right\|_{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\lesssim p\sqrt{\epsilon}\left(B\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}+G+\sigma\right) (12)

uniformly over all possible dropout patterns on round tğ‘¡t. The result is stated in LemmaÂ 2 (presented in Appendix C.1.1). Surprisingly, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-fraction of maliciously chosen unavailable clients can contribute a deviation of Oâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ‘‚italic-ÏµO(\sqrt{\epsilon}). The rate turns out to be optimal as the estimation error matches the fundamental limit in TheoremÂ 4.

Combining together.

Once we have tight upper bounds on the bias, the remaining steps are mostly similar to the standard SGD analysis. Specifically,

Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸t=Î²â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(Î¸i,t+1âˆ’Î¸t)subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}(\theta_{i,t+1}-\theta_{t}) =âˆ’Î²â€‹sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)+Î²â€‹Btğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒabsentğ›½ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒ\displaystyle=-\beta s\eta_{t}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})+\beta B_{t}^{\sf obj}
=âˆ’Î²â€‹sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)+Î²â€‹Btğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒ+Î²â€‹sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹Btğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…,absentğ›½ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒğ›½ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…\displaystyle=-\beta s\eta_{t}\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})+\beta B_{t}^{\sf obj}+\beta s\eta_{t}B_{t}^{\sf sel},

where ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Btğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒâ€–2|â„±t]ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—ƒ2subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}[\|{B_{t}^{\sf obj}}\|_{2}|{\mathcal{F}}_{t}] and ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Btğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…â€–2|â„±t]ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ—Œğ–¾ğ—…2subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}[\|{B_{t}^{\sf sel}}\|_{2}|{\mathcal{F}}_{t}] are upper bounded byÂ (11) and (12), respectively. Applying the above analysis in (10), we obtain the progress in one communication round, which further yields upper bounds of â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2subscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\|_{2} via suitable scheduling of learning rates. See details in AppendixÂ C.1.

5 Minimax lower bounds

Theorem 4.

Given any algorithm (including randomized and non-FL algorithm) and any time horizon Tğ‘‡T (including T=âˆğ‘‡T=\infty), there always exists a choice of Mğ‘€M functions {â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸):iâˆˆ[M],tâˆˆ[T]}conditional-setsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡\{\ell_{i,t}(\theta):i\in[M],t\in[T]\} for which i) each â„“i,tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡\ell_{i,t} is Lğ¿L-smooth and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex; ii) Fiâ€‹(Î¸)â‰œğ”¼â€‹[â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)]â‰œsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœƒğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒF_{i}(\theta)\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[\ell_{i,t}(\theta)\right] satisfies the (B,G)ğµğº(B,G) condition; iii) ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸))â‰¤Ïƒi2ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒsubscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘–\mathsf{var}(\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta))\leq\sigma^{2}_{i}, and a choice of ğ’®tâŠ‚[M]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘€{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\subset[M] for tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T] with |ğ’®t|â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹Msubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡1italic-Ïµğ‘€|{\mathcal{S}}_{t}|\geq(1-\epsilon)M such that the output of the algorithm Î¸^^ğœƒ\widehat{\theta} given access to {â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸):iâˆˆğ’®t,tâˆˆ[T]}conditional-setsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒformulae-sequenceğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡\{\ell_{i,t}(\theta):i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t},t\in[T]\} has an error at least

ğ”¼â€‹[â„›â€‹(Î¸^)]â‰¥Ïµ8â€‹(1âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2).ğ”¼delimited-[]â„›^ğœƒitalic-Ïµ81italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathcal{R}}(\widehat{\theta})\right]\geq\frac{\epsilon}{8(1-\epsilon)}\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right). (13)

We have shown in Theorems 2 and 3 that the lower bound inÂ (13) can be attained by simple variants of the standard FedAvg and FedProx algorithm with only access to noisy gradients and even when the adversary can adaptively choose ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} based on all the past history information. Combining this result withÂ TheoremÂ 4 implies that Ïµâ€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2superscriptğœ2\epsilon\left(G^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right) is minimax optimal.

Proof sketch and comparison of lower bounds. To deduce that the lower bound inÂ (13) is at least on the order of Ïµâ€‹G2italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2\epsilon G^{2}, it suffices to construct time-invariant ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. We construct two instances: one homogeneous instance where â„“i,t=fsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘“\ell_{i,t}=f for all i,tğ‘–ğ‘¡i,t; and the other heterogeneous instance where â„“i,t=fsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘“\ell_{i,t}=f for iâˆˆSğ‘–ğ‘†i\in S and â„“i,t=gsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘”\ell_{i,t}=g for iâˆ‰Sğ‘–ğ‘†i\notin S for some fixed SâŠ‚[M]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘€S\subset[M] with |S|=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹Mğ‘†1italic-Ïµğ‘€|S|=(1-\epsilon)M. The functions fğ‘“f and gğ‘”g are properly chosen to be sufficiently distinct while satisfying the (B,G)ğµğº(B,G)-condition. Importantly, if the adversary chooses ğ’®t=Ssubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘†{\mathcal{S}}_{t}=S for all tğ‘¡t, then any algorithm with access to {â„“i,t:iâˆˆğ’®t}conditional-setsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\{\ell_{i,t}:i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\} cannot distinguish the two instances and hence cannot simultaneously optimize both instances. A very similar construction of the two instances has been used inÂ [KHJ22, Theorem III] to prove that the same lower bound Ïµâ€‹G2italic-Ïµsuperscriptğº2\epsilon G^{2} holds for a static Byzantine attack where the adversary can choose a pre-selected ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} and corrupt {â„“i,t,iâˆ‰ğ’®}subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ’®\{\ell_{i,t},i\notin{\mathcal{S}}\} by arbitrary errors.

In contrast, to prove the lower bound on the order of Ïµâ€‹Ïƒ2italic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ2\epsilon\sigma^{2}, it is crucial to have ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} be time-varying and chosen based on the realization of {â„“i,t,iâˆˆ[M]}subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€\{\ell_{i,t},i\in[M]\}. In particular, we again construct two instances. The first instance is exactly the same as before. The second instance is also the same, except that Sğ‘†S is replaced by Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t} that is chosen uniformly and independently at random from all subsets of [M]delimited-[]ğ‘€[M] with size (1âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹M1italic-Ïµğ‘€(1-\epsilon)M. This time the functions fğ‘“f and gğ‘”g are chosen to be sufficiently distinct while the variance of âˆ‡â„“i,tâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡\nabla\ell_{i,t} is kept at most Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. Now, if the adversary chooses ğ’®t=Stsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}=S_{t}, then any algorithm with access to {â„“i,t:iâˆˆğ’®t}conditional-setsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\{\ell_{i,t}:i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\} cannot distinguish the two instances and hence cannot simultaneously optimize both instances. Note that the previous workÂ [KHJ22] assumes the adversary is static and chooses a prefixed ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} to inject errors; thus the lower boundÂ [KHJ22, Theorem III] does not contain the Ïµâ€‹Ïƒ2italic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ2\epsilon\sigma^{2} term as we do. For this reason, when G=0ğº0G=0 they show that an FL algorithm with a robust aggregator of noisy gradients can approach the zero optimization error as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\to\infty. However, this is fundamentally impossible in our setting with non-static adversarial dropouts.

Remark 2 (The impact of dissimilarity parameter BğµB).

The lower bound in TheoremÂ 4 does not depend on the other dissimilarity parameter B.ğµB. From the analysis of our algorithm, the parameter BğµB in AssumptionÂ 1 instead influences the convergence speed and the requirement on the learning rate; the eventual precision is unaffected.

Remark 3 (Convergence rate in Tğ‘‡T).

Our lower bound does not capture the dependency on T.ğ‘‡T. It is known in the literature that even in the centralized homogeneous setting, any algorithm with access to Tğ‘‡T queries of noisy gradients of Fğ¹F with variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} has to suffer an estimation error ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸^)â€–22]â‰¥Î©â€‹(Ïƒ/T)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹^ğœƒ22Î©ğœğ‘‡\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla F(\widehat{\theta})\|_{2}^{2}\right]\geq\Omega(\sigma/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex Fğ¹F and ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î¸^âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–2]â‰¥Î©â€‹(Î¼2â€‹Ïƒ2/T)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnorm^ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒ2Î©superscriptğœ‡2superscriptğœ2ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}\left[\|\widehat{\theta}-\theta^{*}\|^{2}\right]\geq\Omega(\mu^{2}\sigma^{2}/T) for Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex Fğ¹F in the worst case (see e.g., [ACD+22, Theorem 3] andÂ [GHZH21, Theorem E.1]).

6 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we use numerical experiments to corroborate our theories and analysis on both real-world and synthetic datasets. Specifically, we evaluate the proposed variants of FedAvg and FedProx on balanced real-world dataset (CIFAR-10 [KH+09]) and imbalanced Synthetic (1,1)11\left(1,1\right) dataset (see AppendixÂ E.2) [SSZ14, LSZ+20] with different heterogeneity which will be specified later. The results on synthetic dataset are deferred toÂ AppendixÂ E due to space limitation. In each round, K=10ğ¾10K=10 clients are sampled uniformly at random without replacement from M=100ğ‘€100M=100 clients to build ğ’®~t.subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}. Let us denote by Ïµtsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon_{t} the actual dropout fraction in round t,ğ‘¡t, i.e., Ïµtâ‰œ(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~tâˆ–ğ’®tni)/(Kâ€‹N/M).â‰œsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘€\epsilon_{t}\triangleq(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}n_{i})/(KN/M). The amplification factor Î²ğ›½\beta is tuned from grid search and is set as Î²=M/K=10ğ›½ğ‘€ğ¾10\beta=M/K=10 throughout. All the results are averaged from at least two different random seeds. The missing hyper-parameters and hardware setup can be found in the following subsections and inÂ AppendixÂ E.

Each of the evaluations contains two parts:
(1) Comparisons with the baselines: FedAvg [MMR+17], FedProx [LSZ+20], and MIFA [GHZH21] algorithms. Momentum SGD is used as the local solver for FedProx. For ease of presentation, we name FedAvg, MIFA, and our FedAvg variant as FedAvg-type henceforth as they share the same structures of local computations.
(2) Comparisons with Byzantine-resilient algorithms: centered clipping (cclip) [KHJ21], geometric median (GM) [CSX17], and their bucketing variants [KHJ22]. [KHJ22, Section 5] argued that momentum is helpful in reducing clientsâ€™ variance in stochastic gradients. This setting is adopted hereafter for the Byzantine-resilient algorithms. Since the original Byzantine-resilient algorithms in [KHJ22] do not account for either partial client participation or local computations, we let the parameter server reuse the inactive clientsâ€™ one-step (s=1ğ‘ 1s=1) momentum from the last active rounds, analogous to MIFA, for a fair comparison. The active clients still update their latest momentum to the parameter server for aggregation. Similar to [KHJ22], we set 222 buckets for the bucketing variants.

6.1 Adversarial client unavailability scheme

Recall from Section 3 that the set of participating clients ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} is constructed as follows. First, the parameter server samples Kğ¾K clients uniformly at random without replacement to establish a set ğ’®~t.subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}. Then the system adversary will, subject to satisfying Assumption 2, shrink the set ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} by selecting some clients to be non-responsive. We aim to have the adversary silence the clients whose gradient changes are the most significant. Towards this, we construct a candidate non-responsive client set ğ’~~ğ’\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} based on the executions of two shadow experiments â€“ FedAvg-shadow and cclip-shadow; the set ğ’~~ğ’\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} will be used by the adversary to determine time-varying ğ’®~tâˆ–ğ’®tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. FedAvg-shadow and cclip-shadow are independent executions of FedAvg and cclip yet with full client participation. Their local datasets are independently generated from the same non-IID distributions as those in the regular experiments but using different random seeds. The usage of different random seeds ensures the construction of set ğ’~~ğ’\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}} does not use future information in regular experiments.

Once the shadow experiments are done, we select the top K1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ¾1â€²K_{1}^{\prime} clients with the highest |â€–âˆ‘Ï„=0sâˆ’1âˆ‡â„“i,T2Ï„â€‹(Î¸i,T2Ï„)â€–âˆ’â€–âˆ‘Ï„=0sâˆ’1âˆ‡â„“i,T1Ï„â€‹(Î¸i,T1Ï„)â€–|normsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0ğ‘ 1âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡2ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡2ğœnormsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0ğ‘ 1âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡1ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡1ğœ|\|\sum_{\tau=0}^{s-1}\nabla\ell_{i,T_{2}}^{\tau}\left(\theta_{i,T_{2}}^{\tau}\right)\|-\|\sum_{\tau=0}^{s-1}\nabla\ell_{i,T_{1}}^{\tau}\left(\theta_{i,T_{1}}^{\tau}\right)\||Â 222Any pair of round indices with sufficient separation will also work. In fact, our scheme can be readily extended to multiple pairs of such round indices. under FedAvg-shadow to from ğ’~1subscript~ğ’1\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}. Similarly, we compute |â€–ğ’jT2â€–âˆ’â€–ğ’jT1â€–|normsuperscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‡2normsuperscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‡1|\|\bm{m}_{j}^{T_{2}}\|-\|\bm{m}_{j}^{T_{1}}\|| for jâˆˆ[M]âˆ–ğ’~1ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘€subscript~ğ’1j\in[M]\setminus\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1} under cclip-shadow and then choose the top K2â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ¾â€²2K^{\prime}_{2} clients with the largest momentum changes to form ğ’~2subscript~ğ’2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2}. Notably, ğ’~1âˆ©ğ’~2=âˆ….subscript~ğ’1subscript~ğ’2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}\cap\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2}=\emptyset. Let ğ’~=ğ’~1âˆªğ’~2~ğ’subscript~ğ’1subscript~ğ’2\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}=\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{1}\cup\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}_{2} whose |ğ’~|â‰œKâ€²=K1â€²+K2â€²â‰œ~ğ’superscriptğ¾â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ¾â€²1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾â€²2|\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}|\triangleq K^{\prime}=K^{\prime}_{1}+K^{\prime}_{2}.

Now, we are ready to present how the adversary forms ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t} based on C~~ğ¶\widetilde{C} and ğ’®~tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t} in regular experiments. In each round, let (i1t,â€¦,iKt)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ¾\left(i^{t}_{1},\ldots,i^{t}_{K}\right) denote the indices of the clients in ğ’®t~~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}} after random permutation, and let ğ’®tâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime} be an intermediate set which is set as S~tsubscript~ğ‘†ğ‘¡\widetilde{S}_{t} initially and is used to iteratively build ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. For each kğ‘˜k, the system adversary decides whether to silence client iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k} or not based on two criteria: i) ikâˆˆğ’~subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜~ğ’i_{k}\in\widetilde{{\mathcal{C}}}; ii) âˆ‘iâˆˆ(ğ’®~tâˆ–ğ’®tâ€²)âˆª{ik}niâ‰¤Ïµâ€‹Kâ€‹N/M.subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘ğ‘€\sum_{i\in\left(\widetilde{{\mathcal{S}}}_{t}\setminus{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}}\right)\cup\left\{i_{k}\right\}}n_{i}\leq\epsilon KN/M. If both are satisfied, then ğ’®tâ€²â†ğ’®tâ€²âˆ–{ik}â†superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}\leftarrow{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}\setminus\{i_{k}\}. This procedure is iterated from i1subscriptğ‘–1i_{1} to iKsubscriptğ‘–ğ¾i_{K} or until |ğ’®tâ€²|=1superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²1\left|{{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}}\right|=1 to avoid trivial boundary case. Finally, ğ’®tâ†ğ’®tâ€²â†subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡â€²{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\leftarrow{\mathcal{S}}_{t}^{\prime}.

6.2 Experiments on CIFAR-10

Following [HQB19], the CIFAR-10 dataset is partitioned to build each clientsâ€™ local datasets according to the Dirichlet allocation with parameter Î±.ğ›¼\alpha. The local datasets are balanced with ni=100subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–100n_{i}=100 for iâˆˆ[M]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€i\in[M] per round. The experiments elapse T=2000ğ‘‡2000T=2000 communication rounds, and all the active clients compute s=25ğ‘ 25s=25 local steps for FedAvg-type in each round. We run the experiments with Î±=0.1,ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, which creates highly non-IID local datasets. Only the results with Ïµ=0.8italic-Ïµ0.8\epsilon=0.8 are presented here, the results with the other choices of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon can be found inÂ AppendixÂ E. We use LeNet-5 [LBBH98] with cross-entropy loss as the network model. The learning rate Î·t=Î·0/t+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘¡1\eta_{t}=\eta_{0}/\sqrt{t+1} decays with respect to communication rounds with Î·0subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{0} tuned from a grid for FedAvg-type, while the others use constant learning rates. We do not use weight decay or the other kinds of learning rate decay. For ease of presentation, the data points are sampled every 15 communication rounds to smooth the plots. The full plot and other details are deferred toÂ AppendixÂ E.

We observe from Fig.â€‰1 that the proposed variants of FedAvg and FedProx outperform all the other algorithms. Compared with the naive FedAvg and FedProx, our variants progress smoother, and the improvements are quite prominent. Notably, MIFA acts better than FedAvg but falls behind our variants. The second row of Fig.â€‰1(a) illustrates that the adversarial client unavailability scheme in Section 6.1 obeys Assumption 2 and creates a highly adversarial environment, where only 222 clients participate in the training per round. On the other hand, the Byzantine-resilient algorithms lag behind the proposed algorithms significantly. Detailed discussions on existing Byzantine-resilient algorithms can be found inÂ AppendixÂ A.

Appendix A Related work on Byzantine-resilient distributed and federated learning

Byzantine attack is a canonical adversary model in distributed computing [Lyn96]. In general, it includes two key aspects: (A.1) adversarial client selection, i.e., the compromised clients can be selected in the worst possible manner based on the knowledge of the system states, and (A.2) malicious value injection, i.e., the compromised clients inject arbitrary values into the system. An illustration can be found inÂ Fig.Â 2. More importantly, the subset of compromised clients may vary over time [BDPPBT19, Lyn96, CM16], and can be adaptively chosen by the system adversary. Tolerating Byzantine attacks in distributed and federated learning have received intensive attention recently [FXM14, SG15, SV16, BEMGS17, CSX17, YCKB18, XKG19, GMK+20, KHJ21, KHJ22, FGG+22, AFG+23]. Our adversarial unavailability model can be viewed as a special case of Byzantine attacks with adversarial client selection [i.e.â€‰(A.1)] but no malicious value injection [i.e.,(A.2)]. Nevertheless, as we explain next, to the best of our knowledge, existing Byzantine-resilient results are not applicable to our problem.

Both (A.1) and (A.2) that are adaptive to history information were considered in [CSX17, YCKB18, SX19] yet under the simplified setting such as IID datasets, strongly-convex objectives, and one-step local updates. To handle the attack adaptivity in both (A.1) and (A.2), algorithm convergence was shown via deriving uniform concentration bounds over the entire model hypothesis set. When the datasets are non-IID or unbalanced, unfortunately, their analysis breaks apart. Assuming the subset of Byzantine clients is fixed and pre-selected throughout training, a more recent line of workÂ [FGG+22, KHJ21, KHJ22] focused on (A.2) only. IID local data is considered in [FGG+22, KHJ21]. Karimireddy et al.â€‰[KHJ21] proposed a novel algorithm that uses centered clipping at the parameter server for robust gradient aggregation, and adopts stochastic gradient momentum at each client to enhance robustness against time coupled attacks 333After a close check on the analysis in [KHJ21], we spotted a caveat in their Lemma 9; the clientsâ€™ momentum is not independent due to the global model update, which violates the requirements of their Definition C. Consequently, Lemma 9 and Theorem VI in [KHJ21] are problematic.. Extending their convergence analysis to a non-IID setting is challenging unless imposing strong assumptions such as common stationary points (i.e.Â G=0ğº0G=0) or absolute bounded gradient dissimilarity (i.e.Â B=0ğµ0B=0). It is crucial to assume the subset of Byzantine clients is fixed and pre-selected for the analysis in [KHJ22, AFG+23]. When the system adversary can adaptively compromise the clients

the mean of each Byzantine-free bucket in [KHJ22] is no longer unbiased444In each round, the method in [KHJ22] uniformly at random partitions data into multiple buckets. The mathematical correctness of their proposed method requires that, in expectation, the mean of the data in each Byzantine-free bucket is the same as the average of the non-corrupted data, where the expectation is taken over the random data partition. Here a Byzantine-free bucket is a bucket that does not contain any corrupted data. Consider the instance wherein there are four data points {1,2,3,4}1234\{1,2,3,4\}, and at most one of them can be corrupted. Uniformly at random partition the four data points into two groups each with two data points. For each given partition, we choose the group with the larger mean and corrupt the smallest element. A simple enumeration shows that the mean of the Byzantine-free bucket is strictly smaller than the average of non-corrupted data.. To tolerate time-varying subsets of Byzantine clients, the (f,Îº)ğ‘“ğœ…(f,\kappa)-robustness in [AFG+23, Definition 2] requirement needs to be imposed on any client subset of proper size, which is hard to ensure unless the involved quantities follow light-tailed distributions such as subgaussian or subexponential [CSX17, YCKB18, SX19].

Appendix B Characterization of convergence speed in the non-convex case

In CorollaryÂ 1, the O~â€‹(1/T)~ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡\widetilde{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) convergence rate matches that of the standard stochastic gradient descent for optimizing nonconvex functions [GL13]. In fact, the Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) convergence rate is the best possible for any first-order method that has only access to noisy gradients (see e.g.Â [ACD+22, Theorem 3]). When there is no adversarial dropout, our results inÂ CorollaryÂ 1 are comparable to the state-of-the-art convergence results for FedAvg or FedProx. Specifically, For FedAvg, decay terms similar to Î”â€‹B2/TÎ”superscriptğµ2ğ‘‡\Delta B^{2}/T and (G+Ïƒ)/Tğºğœğ‘‡(G+\sigma)/\sqrt{T} also appear inÂ [KKM+20, Thoerem V]. For FedProx, [YL22, Theorem 1] assumes B=0ğµ0B=0 and obtains a decay term similar to (Î”+G2)/TÎ”superscriptğº2ğ‘‡(\Delta+G^{2})/\sqrt{T}.

Proof ofÂ CorollaryÂ 1.

In the first case Î·t=Î·0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{t}=\eta_{0} is a constant for a given Tğ‘‡T. We obtain from TheoremÂ 2 that

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸R)â€–22â‰¤3â€‹Î”Î²â€‹pâ€‹sâ€‹Tâ€‹Î·0+câ€‹(Ïµ+Î²â€‹sâ€‹Lâ€‹Î·0)â€‹(G+Ïƒ)2.ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘…223Î”ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘italic-Ïµğ›½ğ‘ ğ¿subscriptğœ‚0superscriptğºğœ2\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{3\Delta}{\beta psT\eta_{0}}+c\left(\epsilon+\beta sL\eta_{0}\right)\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}.

Plugging Î·0â‰¤1Î²â€‹pâ€‹Tâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)subscriptğœ‚01ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ¿ğºğœ\eta_{0}\leq\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma)} and 1Î·0â‰¤10â€‹Î²â€‹Lâ€‹B2+Î²â€‹pâ€‹Tâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)1subscriptğœ‚010ğ›½ğ¿superscriptğµ2ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ¿ğºğœ\frac{1}{\eta_{0}}\leq 10\beta LB^{2}+\beta\sqrt{pTL}(G+\sigma) yields the desired result.

In the second case Î·t=Î·0/t+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘¡1\eta_{t}=\eta_{0}/\sqrt{t+1}, it follows from TheoremÂ 2 that

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸R)â€–22â‰¤3â€‹Î”Î²â€‹pâ€‹sâ€‹Î·0â€‹âˆ‘t=0T1t+1+câ€‹(Ïµ+Î²â€‹sâ€‹Lâ€‹Î·0â€‹âˆ‘t=0T1t+1âˆ‘t=0T1t+1)â€‹(G+Ïƒ)2.ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘…223Î”ğ›½ğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ‘¡1ğ‘italic-Ïµğ›½ğ‘ ğ¿subscriptğœ‚0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ‘¡1superscriptğºğœ2\mathbb{E}\|{\nabla F(\theta_{R})}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{3\Delta}{\beta ps\eta_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}}+c\left(\epsilon+\beta sL\eta_{0}\frac{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{{t+1}}}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}}\right)\left(G+\sigma\right)^{2}.

Note that âˆ‘t=0T1t+1=Î˜â€‹(T)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ‘¡1Î˜ğ‘‡\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{\sqrt{t+1}}=\Theta(\sqrt{T}) and âˆ‘t=0T1t+1=Î˜â€‹(logâ¡T)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ‘¡1Î˜ğ‘‡\sum_{t=0}^{T}\frac{1}{{t+1}}=\Theta(\log T). Plugging Î·0â‰¤1Î²â€‹pâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)subscriptğœ‚01ğ›½ğ‘ğ¿ğºğœ\eta_{0}\leq\frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)} and 1Î·0â‰¤10â€‹Î²â€‹Lâ€‹B2+Î²â€‹pâ€‹Lâ€‹(G+Ïƒ)1subscriptğœ‚010ğ›½ğ¿superscriptğµ2ğ›½ğ‘ğ¿ğºğœ\frac{1}{\eta_{0}}\leq{10\beta LB^{2}}+{\beta\sqrt{pL}(G+\sigma)} yields the conclusion. âˆ

Appendix C Proofs of upper bounds

We first introduce some notations for the local update rules:

  • â€¢

    FedAvg: let ğ’¢i,tâ€‹(Î¸;Î·)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒğœ‚{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}(\theta;\eta) denote the mapping of the gradient descent on client iğ‘–i in round tğ‘¡t with the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta:

    ğ’¢i,tâ€‹(Î¸;Î·)â‰œÎ¸âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸).â‰œsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒğœ‚ğœƒğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}(\theta;\eta)\triangleq\theta-\eta\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta). (14)

    Then, the locally updated model after sğ‘ s steps of gradient descent is

    Î¸i,t+1=ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸t,Î·t),subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\theta_{i,t+1}={\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta_{t},\eta_{t}),

    where

    ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(â‹…;Î·)â‰œğ’¢i,tâ€‹(â‹…;Î·)âˆ˜â‹¯âˆ˜ğ’¢i,tâ€‹(â‹…;Î·)âŸsâ€‹times.â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ â‹…ğœ‚subscriptâŸsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡â‹…ğœ‚â‹¯subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡â‹…ğœ‚ğ‘ times{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\cdot;\eta)\triangleq\underbrace{{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}(\cdot;\eta)\circ\dots\circ{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}(\cdot;\eta)}_{s~{}\text{times}}.
  • â€¢

    FedProx: let ğ’«i,tâ€‹(Î¸,Î·)subscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒğœ‚{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta,\eta) denote proximal mapping defined as

    ğ’«i,tâ€‹(Î¸;Î·)â‰œargâ¡minzâ¡â„“i,tâ€‹(z)+12â€‹Î·â€‹â€–zâˆ’Î¸â€–22.â‰œsubscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒğœ‚subscriptğ‘§subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘§12ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘§ğœƒ22{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta;\eta)\triangleq\arg\min_{z}\ell_{i,t}(z)+\frac{1}{2\eta}\left\|{z-\theta}\right\|_{2}^{2}. (15)

    Then Î¸i,t+1âˆˆğ’«i,tâ€‹(Î¸t;Î·t)subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\theta_{i,t+1}\in{\mathcal{P}}_{i,t}(\theta_{t};\eta_{t}).

After collecting the updated model Î¸i,t+1subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡1\theta_{i,t+1} for iâˆˆğ’®tğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}, PS aggregates the local updates via (2).

C.1 Proof ofÂ TheoremÂ 2

C.1.1 Preliminary steps and auxiliary lemmas

We first prove the results for the FedAvg update rule. Recall that each Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} is Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}-smooth. Hence, Fğ¹F is Lğ¿L-smooth with L=maxiâ¡Liğ¿subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¿ğ‘–L=\max_{i}L_{i} and thus

Fâ€‹(Î¸t+1)â‰¤Fâ€‹(Î¸t)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t),Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tâŸ©+L2â€‹â€–Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tâ€–22.ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ¿2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22F(\theta_{t+1})\leq F(\theta_{t})+\left\langle\nabla F(\theta_{t}),\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. (16)

It follows from our aggregation ruleÂ (2) that, for every tğ‘¡t,

Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} =Î²â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸t;Î·t)âˆ’Î¸t)absentğ›½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta_{t};\eta_{t})-\theta_{t})
=Î²â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹(ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸t;Î·t)âˆ’Î¸t+sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t))âˆ’Î²â€‹sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t).absentğ›½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle=\beta\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta_{t};\eta_{t})-\theta_{t}+s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}))-\beta s\eta_{t}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}). (17)

On the right-hand side ofÂ (17), the second term is similar to the usual stochastic gradient, where we need to deal with the existence of adversarial dropout. Choosing a large sğ‘ s increases the negative drift captured in the second term and thus accelerates the training process. However, it also increases the deviation from the stochastic gradient quantified in the first term, and possibly renders training process unstable as observed in [MMR+17]. To quantify the stability of multiple local gradient steps, define

Îºâ‰œmaxi,tâ¡(1+Î·tâ€‹Li)sâˆ’1âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹Li(s2)â€‹(Î·tâ€‹Li)2.â‰œğœ…subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡superscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘ 1ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–binomialğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–2\kappa\triangleq\max_{i,t}\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{\binom{s}{2}(\eta_{t}L_{i})^{2}}.

Intuitively, Îºğœ…\kappa characterizes the deviation of multiple local gradient descent from a single gradient descent with a larger step size, as shown in LemmaÂ 1. For the special case that s=1ğ‘ 1s=1, we have Îº=0ğœ…0\kappa=0; for sâ‰¥2ğ‘ 2s\geq 2, it always holds that Îºâ‰¥1ğœ…1\kappa\geq 1. Furthermore, Îºâ‰¤ecâˆ’1âˆ’cc2/2ğœ…superscriptğ‘’ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘22\kappa\leq\frac{e^{c}-1-c}{c^{2}/2} if Î·tâ‰¤csâ€‹Lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ ğ¿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{c}{sL}. We have the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

For sâ‰¥1ğ‘ 1s\geq 1, we have

â€–Î¸âˆ’ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2â‰¤Îºâ€‹Î·t2â€‹(s2)â€‹Liâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2,âˆ€Î¸.subscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2ğœ…superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2binomialğ‘ 2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2for-allğœƒ\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\kappa\eta_{t}^{2}\binom{s}{2}L_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2},\quad\forall\theta.
Proof.

By the definition of Îºğœ…\kappa,

Îºâ€‹Î·t2â€‹(s2)â€‹Liâ‰¥(1+Î·tâ€‹Li)sâˆ’1âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹LiLi.ğœ…superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2binomialğ‘ 2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–superscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘ 1ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ¿ğ‘–\kappa\eta_{t}^{2}\binom{s}{2}L_{i}\geq\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{L_{i}}.

Hence it suffices to show

â€–Î¸âˆ’ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2â‰¤(1+Î·tâ€‹Li)sâˆ’1âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹Li(Î·tâ€‹Li)2â€‹Î·t2â€‹Liâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2.subscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2superscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘ 1ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{(1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{s}-1-s\eta_{t}L_{i}}{(\eta_{t}L_{i})^{2}}\eta_{t}^{2}L_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}. (18)

We proveÂ (18) holds for all sâ‰¥1ğ‘ 1s\geq 1 by induction. The base case s=1ğ‘ 1s=1 follows from the definition of gradient mapping ğ’¢i,tsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t} inÂ (14). SupposeÂ (18) holds true for s=1,â€¦,nâˆ’1ğ‘ 1â€¦ğ‘›1s=1,\dots,n-1, where nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. Next we proveÂ (18) for s=nğ‘ ğ‘›s=n. By the telescoping sum

ğ’¢i,tnâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’Î¸=âˆ‘s=0nâˆ’1ğ’¢i,ts+1â€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)=âˆ’Î·tâ€‹âˆ‘s=0nâˆ’1âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)),superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ 1ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0ğ‘›1âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{n}(\theta;\eta_{t})-\theta=\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s+1}(\theta;\eta_{t})-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})=-\eta_{t}\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}\nabla\ell_{i,t}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})),

we obtain

â€–Î¸âˆ’ğ’¢i,tnâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’nâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2subscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2\displaystyle\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{n}(\theta;\eta_{t})-n\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2} =Î·tâ€‹â€–âˆ‘s=0nâˆ’1(âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t))âˆ’âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸))â€–2â‰¤Î·tâ€‹Liâ€‹âˆ‘s=0nâˆ’1â€–ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’Î¸â€–2absentsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0ğ‘›1âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0ğ‘›1subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœƒ2\displaystyle=\eta_{t}\left\|{\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}(\nabla\ell_{i,t}({\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t}))-\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta))}\right\|_{2}\leq\eta_{t}L_{i}\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}\left\|{{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-\theta}\right\|_{2}
â‰¤Î·tâ€‹Liâ€‹âˆ‘s=1nâˆ’1(â€–Î¸âˆ’ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2+sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2),absentsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘›1subscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2\displaystyle\leq\eta_{t}L_{i}\sum_{s=1}^{n-1}\left(\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}+s\eta_{t}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\right), (19)

where in the first inequality we usedÂ (3). Applying the induction hypothesisÂ (18) for s=1,â€¦,nâˆ’1ğ‘ 1â€¦ğ‘›1s=1,\dots,n-1, we get

âˆ‘s=1nâˆ’1â€–Î¸âˆ’ğ’¢i,tsâ€‹(Î¸;Î·t)âˆ’sâ€‹Î·tâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2â‰¤((1+Î·tâ€‹Li)nâˆ’1âˆ’nâ€‹Î·tâ€‹Liâˆ’(n2)â€‹(Î·tâ€‹Li)2)â€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸)â€–2Î·tâ€‹Li2.superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘›1subscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2superscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘›1ğ‘›subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–binomialğ‘›2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–2subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœƒ2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–2\sum_{s=1}^{n-1}\left\|{\theta-{\mathcal{G}}_{i,t}^{s}(\theta;\eta_{t})-s\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}\leq\left((1+\eta_{t}L_{i})^{n}-1-n\eta_{t}L_{i}-\binom{n}{2}(\eta_{t}L_{i})^{2}\right)\frac{\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta)}\right\|_{2}}{\eta_{t}L_{i}^{2}}.

Plugging intoÂ (19), we concludeÂ (18) for s=nğ‘ ğ‘›s=n. The proof is completed. âˆ

For the second term on the right-hand side ofÂ (17), due the adversarial attack, the average of gradients from the participating clients is no longer an unbiased estimate of the population gradient âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F. Fortunately, given the bounded dissimilarity among the local gradients given in AssumptionÂ 1, we can separately control the effect of the adversarial dropout ğ’®~t/ğ’®tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}. Specifically, recall that ğ’®~tâŠ‡ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\supseteq{\mathcal{S}}_{t} is the set of the Kğ¾K clients randomly sampled at round tğ‘¡t. Since Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} is adapted to â„±tsubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡{\mathcal{F}}_{t}, we have

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ£â„±t]ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right] =ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€‹ğŸ{iâˆˆğ’®~t}âˆ£â„±t]absentğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscript1ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}){\mathbf{1}_{\left\{{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}\right\}}}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]
=(a)â€‹âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âˆ£â„±t]â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[ğŸ{iâˆˆğ’®~t}âˆ£â„±t]ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript1ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{=}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathbf{1}_{\left\{{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}\right\}}}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]
=(b)â€‹âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹Fiâ€‹(Î¸t)â€‹pâ€‹=(c)â€‹pâ€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t),ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle\overset{(b)}{=}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}F_{i}(\theta_{t})p\overset{(c)}{=}p\nabla F(\theta_{t}), (20)

where (a) holds because ğ’®~tâŸ‚âŸ‚zi,t|â„±tperpendicular-toabsentperpendicular-tosubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}\mathchoice{\mathrel{\hbox to0.0pt{$\displaystyle\perp$\hss}\mkern 2.0mu{\displaystyle\perp}}}{\mathrel{\hbox to0.0pt{$\textstyle\perp$\hss}\mkern 2.0mu{\textstyle\perp}}}{\mathrel{\hbox to0.0pt{$\scriptstyle\perp$\hss}\mkern 2.0mu{\scriptstyle\perp}}}{\mathrel{\hbox to0.0pt{$\scriptscriptstyle\perp$\hss}\mkern 2.0mu{\scriptscriptstyle\perp}}}z_{i,t}|{\mathcal{F}}_{t}; (b) follows from the sampling fraction ğ”¼â€‹[ğŸ{iâˆˆğ’®~t}âˆ£â„±t]=K/M=pğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript1ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘€ğ‘\mathbb{E}\left[{\mathbf{1}_{\left\{{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}\right\}}}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]=K/M=p; (c) applies (5).

Next, we control the gradients of clients belonging to ğ’®~t/ğ’®tsubscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}.

Lemma 2.

Under AssumptionsÂ 1 and 2, we have

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2âˆ£â„±t]â‰¤pâ€‹Ïµâ€‹(Bâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–2+G+Ïƒ).ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡ğ‘italic-Ïµğµsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2ğºğœ\mathbb{E}\left[\big{\|}\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})\big{\|}_{2}\mid{\mathcal{F}}_{t}\right]\leq p\sqrt{\epsilon}\left(B\left\|{\nabla F(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}+G+\sigma\right).
Proof.

For any tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1, it holds that

â€–âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22\displaystyle\left\|{\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2} =âˆ‘i,jâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹wjâ€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t),âˆ‡â„“j,tâ€‹(Î¸t)âŸ©absentsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\displaystyle=\sum_{i,j\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}w_{j}\left\langle\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t}),\nabla\ell_{j,t}(\theta_{t})\right\rangle
â‰¤(a)â€‹âˆ‘i,jâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹wjâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–22+â€–âˆ‡â„“j,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–222ğ‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡222\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq}\sum_{i,j\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}w_{j}\frac{\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\left\|{\nabla\ell_{j,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}}{2}
=(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twi)â€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–22)absentsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22\displaystyle=\left(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)
â‰¤(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~t/ğ’®twi)â€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®~twiâ€‹â€–âˆ‡â„“i,tâ€‹(Î¸t)â€–22).absentsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡22\displaystyle\leq\left(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}/{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i\in\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}_{t}}w_{i}\left\|{\nabla\ell_{i,t}(\theta_{t})}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right). (21)
