Hyper-parameters: the hyper-parameters are tuned from grid searches: initial learning rates Î·0âˆˆ{10âˆ’4,â€¦,10âˆ’1},subscriptğœ‚0superscript104â€¦superscript101\eta_{0}\in\left\{10^{-4},\ldots,10^{-1}\right\}, amplification factor Î²âˆˆ{1,10,â€¦,100},ğ›½110â€¦100\beta\in\left\{1,10,\ldots,100\right\}, the proximal coefficient Î¼0â‰œ1Î·tâˆˆ{10âˆ’3,â€¦,1},â‰œsubscriptğœ‡01subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscript103â€¦1\mu_{0}\triangleq\frac{1}{\eta_{t}}\in\left\{10^{-3},\ldots,1\right\}, the observation windows are set to be T1=5subscriptğ‘‡15T_{1}=5 and T2=150,subscriptğ‘‡2150T_{2}=150, the selection candidate volumes are K1â€²=25,K2â€²=10.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ¾1â€²25superscriptsubscriptğ¾2â€²10K_{1}^{\prime}=25,K_{2}^{\prime}=10.

Additionally, we list some key elements in Table 1 to avoid confusion, where Î·0subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{0} denotes a constant learning rate but may not refer to the same value for different algorithms. For the numerical calculation of GM, we adopt the smoothed Weiszfeld algorithm from [PKH22]. Note that the iterative centered clipping rule is modified asÂ (43) to adapt to imbalanced training data:

ğ’—l+1=ğ’—l+âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹(Î¸iâˆ’ğ’—l)â€‹minâ¡(1,Ï„lâ€–Î¸iâˆ’ğ’—lâ€–2),subscriptğ’—ğ‘™1subscriptğ’—ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘™1subscriptğœğ‘™subscriptnormsubscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘™2\displaystyle\bm{v}_{l+1}=\bm{v}_{l}+\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\left(\theta_{i}-\bm{v}_{l}\right)\min\left(1,\frac{\tau_{l}}{\left\|{\theta_{i}-\bm{v}_{l}}\right\|_{2}}\right), (43)

where the choice of Ï„l=101âˆ’Î²0subscriptğœğ‘™101subscriptğ›½0\tau_{l}=\frac{10}{1-\beta_{0}} follows from [KHJ22], and Î²0subscriptğ›½0\beta_{0} is the momentum coefficient.

Likewise, Line 9 in Algorithm 1 of [GHZH21] is modified asÂ (44).

Î¸t+1=Î¸tâˆ’Î·tâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹Gi.subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptğºğ‘–\displaystyle\theta_{t+1}=\theta_{t}-\eta_{t}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}G^{i}. (44)

E.1 CIFAR-10

In this section, we present the additional results on CIFAR-10 dataset. Fig.â€‰3 and 4 show the non-smoothed experimental results.

Similar to Section 6.2, we first present the smoothed curves with Ïµ=0.2italic-Ïµ0.2\epsilon=0.2 in Fig.â€‰5 and 6 by sampling every 151515 data points for a clear presentation on the trend. Next, the non-smoothed ones are shown in Fig.â€‰7.

Generally, the observations resemble those from the case of Ïµ=0.8.italic-Ïµ0.8\epsilon=0.8. Our variantsâ€™ trajectories are less noisy than the naive FedAvg and FedProx algorithms. In the baseline comparisons, all the FedAvg-type algorithms achieve comparable performance, while our FedProx variant achieves the best test accuracy. Meanwhile, the Byzantine-robust algorithms, except the naive GM, reach similar results as well. This is intuitive as a total of 888 clients participate in the training per round, which is suggested by the second row of Fig.â€‰5 and in sharp contrast to the highly adversarial case of Ïµ=0.8,italic-Ïµ0.8\epsilon=0.8, where only 222 clients are in the set ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}_{t}.

E.2 Synthetic (1,1)11(1,1)

Overview: Synthetic (1,1) was introduced in [SSZ14, LSZ+20] for FL. We generate samples (Xi,Yi)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–(X_{i},Y_{i}) for each client iğ‘–i according to the model y=argâ¡maxâ¡(softmaxâ€‹(Wâ€‹x+b)),ğ‘¦softmaxğ‘Šğ‘¥ğ‘y=\arg\max\left(\text{softmax}\left(Wx+b\right)\right), where xâˆˆâ„60,ğ‘¥superscriptâ„60x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{60}, Wâˆˆâ„10Ã—60,ğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„1060W\in{\mathbb{R}}^{10\times 60}, bâˆˆâ„10.ğ‘superscriptâ„10b\in{\mathbb{R}}^{10}. To characterize the non-i.i.d. data, we let Wiâˆ¼Nâ€‹(ui,1),biâˆ¼Nâ€‹(ui,1),uiâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Î±=1),formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘0ğ›¼1W_{i}\sim N\left(u_{i},1\right),~{}b_{i}\sim N\left(u_{i},1\right),~{}u_{i}\sim N\left(0,\alpha=1\right), and xiâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(vi,Î£),similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ’©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–Î£x_{i}\sim{\mathcal{N}}\left(v_{i},\Sigma\right), where the covariance matrix is diagonal with âˆ‘j,j=jâˆ’1.2.subscriptğ‘—ğ‘—superscriptğ‘—1.2\sum_{j,j}=j^{-1.2}. Each element in the mean vector visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} is drawn from Nâ€‹(Bi,1),ğ‘subscriptğµğ‘–1N\left(B_{i},1\right), where Biâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Î²=1).similar-tosubscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘0ğ›½1B_{i}\sim N\left(0,\beta=1\right). Each clientsâ€™ data volume follows a power law as shown in Fig.â€‰8.

Implementation: we consider multi-nomial Logistic regression with full batch gradient descent and cross-entropy loss. That is, client iğ‘–iâ€™s batch size equals to its data volume ni.subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}.

Interpretations: the first row of Fig.â€‰9 shows the results without MIFA, whereas the second row is with MIFA. Although the test accuracies in the first row are similar, our variants achieve lower train loss when compared with the naive FedAvg and FedProx.

Due to the imbalance, we cannot guarantee an almost constant dropout fraction Ïµtsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon_{t} like in the balanced CIFAR-10 experiments. This is because the sampled clientsâ€™ data volumes are time-varying in each round. It is possible that the client with the least many data points holds a larger data volume than the threshold Ïµâ€‹Kâ€‹N/M,italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘ğ‘€\epsilon KN/M, and thus no one is droppoed out during that round. However, the dropout scheme ensures that maxtâˆˆ[T]â¡Ïµtâ‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡italic-Ïµ\max_{t\in[T]}\epsilon_{t}\leq\epsilon as suggested by the second row of Fig.â€‰9.

MIFAâ€™s curve resembles a roller coaster ride and does not converge till the end of training. Similarly, Fig.â€‰10 tells us that the Byzantine-robust algorithmsâ€™ fluctuations, which are consistently noisy and do not abate throughout the training, are also severe. A similar trend can be observed from Fig.â€‰11 and 12.

Conclusion Remark: we evaluate the proposed variants on both synthetic and real-world data. In all the experiments, the proposed variants progress smoothly and achieve great, if not best, performance. More importantly, the performance does not demand additional memory, unlike MIFA or the Byzantine-robust MIFA variants.
